title: EU countries agree to suspend arms exports to Turkey
text:
Turkish troops launched an incursion into northern Syria last week | Nazeer Al-Khatib/AFP via Getty Images EU countries agree to suspend arms exports to Turkey The bloc’s foreign ministers also decided to draw up potential sanctions over Ankara’s drilling activities off Cyprus.

EU member states on Monday pledged to suspend weapons exports to Turkey in response to Ankara's incursion into northern Syria, but stopped short of implementing a formal EU-wide arms embargo.

At a meeting of the bloc's foreign ministers in Luxembourg, EU countries also agreed to prepare a list of potential sanctions over Turkey's drilling activities off Cyprus.

In a statement, member states condemned Turkey's military operation in Syria and committed to "strong national positions regarding their arms export policy to Turkey."

EU diplomats say that though this falls short of the EU-wide arms embargo sought by some member states, the effect is the same, while allowing for faster implementation.

Several countries, including Germany, France, Finland and Sweden, have imposed arms embargoes of their own over the past few days.

Turkey launched an incursion into northern Syria last week aimed at driving Syrian Kurdish fighters, which Ankara considers to be terrorists, away from the Syrian-Turkish border. The operation has already displaced some 100,000 people, according to the United Nations.

EU foreign ministers also agreed to draw up a sanctions framework targeting individuals and legal entities in response to Turkey's oil and gas drilling in the Eastern Mediterranean. The decision enables the EU to put together a list of sanctions ready to be issued if and when member states decide to do so.
description: The bloc’s foreign ministers also decided to draw up potential sanctions over Ankara’s drilling activities off Cyprus.
